title: Part (b)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not accurately include either of the criteria below.
The response accurately includes one of the criteria below.
The response accurately includes both of the criteria below.

title: Part (c)
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

The response must both state that the price will increase by less than the amount of the tax and explain why in order to receive the point.
descriptions: The response does not state that the price will increase by less than the amount of the tax and/or does not explain that, unless demand is perfectly inelastic, producers will not be able to raise price by the amount of the tax.

The response states that the price will increase by less than the amount of the tax and explains that, unless demand is perfectly inelastic, producers will not be able to raise price by the amount of the tax.

title: Part (d)
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

The response must both state that the loss in consumer surplus and producer surplus will be greater than the tax revenue collected by the government and explain why in order to receive the point.
descriptions: The response does not state that the loss in consumer and producer surplus will be greater than the tax revenue collected by the government and/or does not explain that the tax reduces the quantity exchanged in the market relative to the unregulated market equilibrium quantity, resulting in a deadweight loss which is equal to the decrease in the total economic surplus.

The response states that the loss in consumer and producer surplus will be greater than the tax revenue collected by the government and explains that the tax reduces the quantity exchanged in the market relative to the unregulated market equilibrium quantity, resulting in a deadweight loss which is equal to the decrease in the total economic surplus.
